channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Why Airline Hijackings Became Relatively Rare
item.description: A more aggressive global response to the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, is one reason that fewer hijackers have attempted what was once relatively commonplace.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK
item.media:credit: Federal Bureau of Investigation, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An artist’s rendering of the hijacker known as “D.B. Cooper,” was made from the recollections of passengers and crew of an airplane hijacked between Portland,Ore., and Seattle in 1971.

item.title: Memo From Moscow: Russia Shows What Happens When Terrorists’ Families Are Targeted
item.description: Donald J. Trump was widely condemned when he called for the United States to “take out the families” of terrorists. But Russia has been doing that for years.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Russian soldiers patrolling a Chechen village in December 2000. Russia found that abductions of militants’ family members were effective in unwinding the rebel leadership in Chechnya.

item.title: Children Pay ‘Highest Price’ as Yemen Falls Apart, U.N. Says
item.description: The conflict and the deteriorating humanitarian conditions in the Middle Eastern country put it at risk of becoming a failed state, Unicef reported.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: A boy who lost his leg in the Yemen war walking with a prosthetic limb at a rehabilitation center in Sanaa, Yemen, this month.

item.title: Sinosphere: China to Survey Children Left Behind by Migrant Workers
item.description: Researchers say these children often suffer from anxiety and depression in the absence of their parents, and exhibit high rates of juvenile delinquency.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG
item.media:description: Children of migrant workers lining up for lunch in an unofficial school in Beijing.

item.title: India Lets Pakistani Team Examine Site of January Attack by Militants
item.description: At least six militants infiltrated an air base, digging themselves in and engaging in a dayslong gun battle with India’s security forces before they were killed.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Pakistani investigators and Indian officials visited the Pathankot air base in Punjab on Tuesday to inspect the site of a deadly attack carried out by militants in January.

item.title: EgyptAir Hijacking Suspect Arrested in Cyprus
item.description: A man claiming to wear an explosive vest forced an EgyptAir plane to land in Larnaca, Cyprus, before being arrested. All the passengers have been freed.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A man climbed out of the cockpit window of a hijacked EgyptAir flight at Larnaca International Airport in Cyprus on Monday.

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.

item.title: Indonesian Sailors Kidnapped by Pirates in Philippines
item.description: Hijackers, claiming to represent a militant group, are demanding ransom for a tugboat’s crew, officials from Indonesia and the Philippines said.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Indonesian Foreign Ministry/Rasto, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Retno Marsudi, Indonesia’s minister of foreign affairs, speaking in Jakarta on Tuesday after hijackers seized 10 crew members from a tugboat and barge off the Philippines.

item.title: Sinosphere: Editor Says He Is Resigning Over Media Controls in China
item.description: An editor at Southern Metropolis Daily posted a message online saying he could no longer “follow your surname,” a reference to the Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping visited the state broadcaster China Central Television last month, where he spoke to staff members about the importance of following party directives.

item.title: Israel Changes Tack After Standoff With Brazil Over Dani Dayan
item.description: Plans to name the former settler leader as envoy to the South American nation were dropped after Brasília refused to approve the appointment.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The former settler leader Dani Dayan, who has been appointed consul general in New York, at a conference in Jerusalem on Monday on fighting a boycott against Israeli goods.

item.title: If All Else Fails, 3D Models and Robots Might Rebuild Sites
item.description: Cultural organizations have been working to create precise 3D digital models of the threatened heritage monuments in Palmyra, Syria, in case the originals are damaged beyond repair.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN FARRELL
item.media:credit: Institute for Digital Archaeology and Tor Art
item.media:description: A small-scale reproduction of a Roman triumphal arch in Palmyra being carved from a 3D computer model in Carrara, Italy, this month. The original arch in Palmyra was destroyed by ISIS.

item.title: Editorial: Another Bombing, This Time in Pakistan
item.description: The Pakistani government has long cynically used Taliban groups as proxy fighters.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: Mourning for the victims of the suicide bombing in Lahore, Pakistan.

item.title: Editorial: Mr. Trump’s Dangerous Babble on Foreign Policy
item.description: Donald Trump offers up disturbing, incoherent views on nuclear weapons and other national security issues.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Scenes From Palmyra Indicate ISIS Slowed Assault on Treasures
item.description: A day after Syrian troops recaptured the city, television footage showed “severe” damage to ancient sculptures. But there was hope that many works could be reconstructed.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Syria’s antiquities director, Maamoun Abdulkarim, said 80 percent of the Unesco World Heritage site encompassing the ancient ruins of Palmyra was intact.

item.title: World Briefing: Cameroon: Doubts That Bomber is Kidnapped Student
item.description: The authorities in Cameroon expressed doubt that a would-be suicide bomber was one of the Nigerian schoolgirls kidnapped by Boko Haram in 2014.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: U.N. Decision Expands Maritime Territory
item.description: The move expanded Argentina’s territory in the South Atlantic Ocean by 35 percent to include the disputed Falkland Islands and beyond.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: President Won’t Fund Leftist TV Network
item.description: Argentina’s president, Mauricio Macri, will cut its funding of a regional television network started by the Venezuelan government in 2005.
item.dc:creator: FREDERICK BERNAS

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: More Peacekeepers Accused
item.description: The United Nations is investigating two new suspected cases of sexual abuse committed by peacekeepers in the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Keen Pain in Pakistan Over Lives ‘Shattered Into Pieces’
item.description: Grief enveloped Pakistan after an instant of calculated cruelty thrust families onto a long roll call of bombing victims. “Within minutes, I lost my wife,” a man said. “I couldn’t save her.”
item.dc:creator: DANIYAL HASSAN, NAILA INAYAT and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: ‘Lula,’ Ex-President of Brazil, Lashes Out at Judge Overseeing Corruption Inquiry
item.description: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva said the judge, Sergio Moro, was trying to ruin him by releasing intercepts of his telephone conversations.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil, shown Monday, accused the judge looking into the country’s graft scandal of trying to ruin him.
